column4: I don't know very much about C++, but that's because I'm too lazy to learn it. My plan is to stick with Java and Python where I can, and C# and .NET where I must.
ditto for C and ASM
I actually liked writing MIPS ASM, but it's sort of like using a 10lb sledge to hammer in a nail to hang a picture.
I could never wrap my head around asm, and with x64 i hear its nearly impossible, if you have any book reccomendations please let me know
I imagine a lot of the slowness of modern java is just bad coding practices. Good code is fast. Bad code isn't. :)
yes I agree, Java allows that, whereas C++ doesn't.. as much.
I've found that python can be slow too, but generally it's slow in places you don't care about. It's really nice for whipping some code together really fast.
I thought lisp would be better than python for those cases?
throwing together a prototype? Eh. From what I've seen of Lisp, it's elegent, but not easy to work with. too many parenthesis.
I know racket and schem so I'm used to it :P. it works within emacs flawlessly too.. that's my excuse
Learning Python from O'Reilly is pretty good, and http://tinyurl.com/thinkcspy is supposed to be excellent.
My suggestion is to avoid perl, from personal experience. It's really really fun when you're first learning it, but all the object oriented stuff feels kludged together to me.
It's hard to beat CPAN in terms of sheer number of modules, but I spent a lot of time fooling around with Perl defaults.
I've never programmed it before all i know is it integrates well in webservers
there is a lot of weirness. I always feel like someone waves their hands and yells "Abracadabra" when I run a perl script. There are a lot of weird default variables and stuff
also bookmarked your linlk
Programming Python (also an O'Reilly book) is pretty awesome too
http://duke.csc.villanova.edu/jss1/ my uni used this book. it was pretty good
10,000 hours is expert level supposedly :)
care to share soe of those? I took one cpsc course in uni so far
I already do :) Most of em are out in the hands of other CS students.
